Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[A11y]Focus order on Organization Management is not correct." (#9420) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Url: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1744473

Environment Details:
App name: NuGet Service
#URL: [https://www.nuget.org](https://nam06.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https:%2f%2fwww.nuget.org%2f&data=05%7c01%7cv-nitipi%40microsoft.com%7c9a84307e7aa744a4b24208dafa5ca2fe%7c72f988bf86f141af91ab2d7cd011db47%7c1%7c0%7c638097573052590837%7cUnknown%7cTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7c3000%7c%7c%7c&sdata=C8Eab3i6ixAmqsOjG4AxNT36z9WZQiXPbjDDkMcS5ME%3D&reserved=0)

OS and Browser Details:
Edition Windows 11 Enterprise
OS build 22621.1105.
Chrome version:  109.0.5414.120 (Official Build) (64-bit)

Repro Steps:
Hit the URL: https://www.nuget.org/
Navigate to "Sign in" control and hit enter.
Navigate to "Sign in with Microsoft" control and hit enter.
Select ‚ÄúManage Organizations‚Äù from the Profile Dropdown and hit enter.
Navigate to "Add New" control and hit enter.
Enter values in "Organization Name" and "Organization Email Address" and hit enter on "Add" Control.
Again Select ‚ÄúManage Organizations‚Äù from the Profile Dropdown and hit enter.
"Organizations" screen gets opened.
Navigate to Member and press enter.
Observe whether the focus order is incorrect after pressing "View Member Profile"

Actual Result:
The focus order is not in left to right order after expanding "View Member Profile"

Expected Result:
Keyboard focus order should move in logical order after pressing tab key "View member profile, Combo box and then Close button".

Notes:
This is probably due to the order of the elements in the DOM not matching the displayed order, as tab order is handled by browser (unless we explicitly override it)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[A11y]Keyboard Focus is not visible in some locations" (#9416) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Url: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1743910

Environment Details:
App name: NuGet Service
#URL: [https://www.nuget.org](https://nam06.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https:%2f%2fwww.nuget.org%2f&data=05%7c01%7cv-nitipi%40microsoft.com%7c9a84307e7aa744a4b24208dafa5ca2fe%7c72f988bf86f141af91ab2d7cd011db47%7c1%7c0%7c638097573052590837%7cUnknown%7cTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7c3000%7c%7c%7c&sdata=C8Eab3i6ixAmqsOjG4AxNT36z9WZQiXPbjDDkMcS5ME%3D&reserved=0)

OS and Browser Details:
Edition Windows 11 Enterprise Insider Preview
OS build 25275.1000.
Chrome version:  109.0.5414.120 (Official Build) (64-bit)

Repro Steps:
Hit the URL: https://www.nuget.org/
Navigate to "Sign in" control and hit enter.
Navigate to "Sign in with Microsoft" control and hit enter.
Select ‚ÄúAPI Keys‚Äù from the Profile Dropdown and hit enter.
Navigate to "Create" button and hit enter.
Enter Values in "Key Name" and "Glob Pattern" field and hit enter on Create button.
Navigate to "Manage" control and hit enter.
Observe whether "edit, Regenerate, delete" keyboard focus is clearly visible or not visible.

Similar issue is observed for below screen also.

Hit the URL: https://www.nuget.org/
Navigate to "Sign in" control and hit enter.
Navigate to "Sign in with Microsoft" control and hit enter.
Search for a key term (say ‚Äújson‚Äù) from search box.
Click on "Newtonsoft.json" control and hit enter.
Navigate to "Owners" section present on bottom right of the screen.
Observe whether "Profile" keyboard focus is clearly visible or not visible.

Actual Result:
Keyboard focus on "Edit, Regenerate, delete" is not clearly visible.

Expected Result:
Keyboard focus should be completely visible on the control wherever focus lands. It should be visible on all four sides on "Edit, Regenerate, Delete".

Notes:
The display (inline) and the packing of the elements around these appear to be covering the area that they keyboard focus border is highlighting. Unfortunately, it is not as easy as adding additional padding/margin around the elements as the inline display prevents some of the height changes. We will need to experiment with this a bit more to figure out a view with enough spacing to be able to see our keyboard focus.

After:

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[A11y][TFM]TFM selection filters do not announce expanded/collapsed state" (#9451) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Url: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1751374

Environment Details:
Application Name: Filtering by Target Frameworks
#URL: [NuGet Gallery | Packages (nugettest.org)](https://dev.nugettest.org/packages?q=)
Windows Version: Win11
OS Version: 22621.1105
Chromium Edge Version: Version 109.0.1518.78 (Official build) (64-bit)
Chrome Version: Version 110.0.5481.77 (Official Build) (64-bit)
Screen reader version: Narrator/ NVDA 2022.2

Repro Steps: 
Hit the URL: [NuGet Gallery | Packages (nugettest.org)](https://dev.nugettest.org/packages?q=)
Tab to Frameworks section.
Tab to the collapse/expand buttons present in the Frameworks section.
Turn on Narrator/NVDA.
Observe that screen reader is not announcing the state whether collapsed/expanded or hidden/shown for the control 'shows and hides TFM filter'.

User Impact:
Screen reader users will be confused if the state of the control is not announced.

Notes:
This would appear to be due to the keyboard focused element not being properly tagged with aria-expanded. Adding this to the proper control element should resolve this.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Packages.lock.json different when built from msbuild versus visuaal studio" (#12527) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

MSBuild.exe, NuGet.exe

### Product Version

msbuild 17.5.1.16304

### Worked before?

never

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

Given a solution (such as the one mentioned in this same issue, which was marked as released https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/8272).  Use central package management.

If you do a msbuild via command line, the packages.lock.json use DLL names for dependancies on a nuget restore.  If you open visual studio and do a build, it uses the Project names, as well as adds more to the packages.lock.json.  

In the screenshot below, the left is msbuild, the right is visual studio.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/55808281/229877656-ef8f8fa8-66e6-4c07-8666-456c992f0cd9.png)

This issue has been mentioned elsewhere on github, but they're all marked as fixed or closed.  It is definately still an issue for me (VS2022 17.5.3, winforms)


### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "References Drawn through NuGet do not respect the `required` keyword" (#12526) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe, Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

dotnet 7.0.100, VS 2022

### Worked before?

New feature

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

I'm unsure this is the correct place, but it's the best I've been able to come up with.

Create a library that provides data types that use the new `required` keyword.

If you directly reference that package, the compiler generates errors/warnings indicating that you are not setting properties so marked.

If you reference the same DLL via a Nuget Package, no errors are created.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug]: NuGet.targets(1 32,5): error : Ambiguous project name" (#12525) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
---
**Issue moved from dotnet/msbuild#8628**
- Please respond to @icnocop.

---

_From @icnocop on Tuesday, April 4, 2023 2:49:52 AM_

### Issue Description

Hi.

When trying to run the "Restore" target on my Visual Studio solution, the following error occurs:

```
C:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio\2022\Enterprise\Common7\IDE\CommonExtensions\Microsoft\NuGet\NuGet.targets(1
32,5): error : Ambiguous project name ...
```

It happens in Visual Studio 2022 and also when using `msbuild` on the command line.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Download and unzip 
[AmbiguousProjectName.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/msbuild/files/11144097/AmbiguousProjectName.zip)
2. Open a Visual Studio 2022 developer command prompt
3. 'CD' into the folder where the folder was created from the zip
4. Run `msbuild /t:Restore`

Alternatively, open the sln in Visual Studio 2022 17.5.3, right click on the root `Solution` node in `Solution Explorer` and select `Restore NuGet Packages`.

### Expected Behavior

I expected the command to succeed.

### Actual Behavior

When using the msbuild command line:
```
MSBuild version 17.5.1+f6fdcf537 for .NET Framework
Building the projects in this solution one at a time. To enable parallel build, please add the "-m" switch.
Build started 4/3/2023 7:36:00 PM.
Included response file: C:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio\2022\Enterprise\MSBuild\Current\Bin\amd64\MSBuild.rsp

Project "C:\github\icnocop\AmbiguousProjectName\AmbiguousProjectName.sln" on node 1 (Restore target(s)).
ValidateSolutionConfiguration:
  Building solution configuration "Debug|Any CPU".
_GetAllRestoreProjectPathItems:
  Determining projects to restore...
Restore:
  X.509 certificate chain validation will use the default trust store selected by .NET.
  X.509 certificate chain validation will use the default trust store selected by .NET.
  Restoring packages for C:\github\icnocop\AmbiguousProjectName\src\Common.NuGet\Common.NuGet.csproj...
C:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio\2022\Enterprise\Common7\IDE\CommonExtensions\Microsoft\NuGet\NuGet.targets(132
,5): error : Ambiguous project name 'Common'. [C:\github\icnocop\AmbiguousProjectName\AmbiguousProjectName.sln]
Done Building Project "C:\github\icnocop\AmbiguousProjectName\AmbiguousProjectName.sln" (Restore target(s)) -- FAILED.


Build FAILED.

"C:\github\icnocop\AmbiguousProjectName\AmbiguousProjectName.sln" (Restore target) (1) ->
(Restore target) ->
  C:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio\2022\Enterprise\Common7\IDE\CommonExtensions\Microsoft\NuGet\NuGet.targets(1
32,5): error : Ambiguous project name 'Common'. [C:\github\icnocop\AmbiguousProjectName\AmbiguousProjectName.sln]

    0 Warning(s)
    1 Error(s)

Time Elapsed 00:00:01.03
```

When using Visual Studio 2022 IDE:
```
Restoring NuGet packages...
Running restore with 12 concurrent jobs.
Reading project file C:\github\icnocop\AmbiguousProjectName\src\Common.NuGet\Common.NuGet.csproj.
The restore inputs for 'Common' have changed. Continuing restore.
Restoring packages for C:\github\icnocop\AmbiguousProjectName\src\Common.NuGet\Common.NuGet.csproj...
NuGet package restore failed. Please see Error List window for detailed warnings and errors.
Time Elapsed: 00:00:00.1047742
========== Finished ==========


Error occurred while restoring NuGet packages: System.InvalidOperationException: Ambiguous project name 'Common'.
   at NuGet.Commands.RestoreCommand.GetProjectReferences()
   at NuGet.Commands.RestoreCommand.<ExecuteRestoreAsync>d__62.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
   at NuGet.Commands.RestoreCommand.<ExecuteAsync>d__45.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
   at NuGet.Commands.RestoreRunner.<ExecuteAsync>d__7.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
   at NuGet.Commands.RestoreRunner.<ExecuteAndCommitAsync>d__6.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
   at NuGet.Commands.RestoreRunner.<CompleteTaskAsync>d__9.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
   at NuGet.Commands.RestoreRunner.<RunAsync>d__2.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
   at NuGet.Commands.RestoreRunner.<RunAsync>d__0.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
   at NuGet.PackageManagement.DependencyGraphRestoreUtility.<RestoreAsync>d__2.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
   at NuGet.SolutionRestoreManager.SolutionRestoreJob.<>c__DisplayClass25_0.<<RestorePackageSpecProjectsAsync>b__2>d.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
   at NuGet.SolutionRestoreManager.RestoreOperationLogger.<RunWithProgressAsync>d__34.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
   at NuGet.SolutionRestoreManager.RestoreOperationLogger.<RunWithProgressAsync>d__34.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
   at NuGet.SolutionRestoreManager.SolutionRestoreJob.<RestorePackageSpecProjectsAsync>d__25.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
   at NuGet.SolutionRestoreManager.SolutionRestoreJob.<RestoreAsync>d__23.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()

--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
   at NuGet.SolutionRestoreManager.SolutionRestoreJob.<ExecuteAsync>d__22.MoveNext()
```

### Analysis

_No response_

### Versions & Configurations

MSBuild version 17.5.1+f6fdcf537 for .NET Framework
17.5.1.16304

Windows 10 Enterprise x64
Version 22H2 (OS Build 19045.2728)

Visual Studio 2022 Enterprise
Version 17.5.3

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "[Test Failure] The vertical scrollbar is truncated in the default layout of Package Manager UI Window" (#3286) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
**Repro Steps:**
1.  New project -> Visual C# -> Web -> ASP.NET Web Application, then uncheck the box for "Application Insights".
2.  Click Web Forms template and check ‚ÄúWeb Forms‚Äù and ‚ÄúWeb API‚Äù.
3.  Change Authentication to ‚ÄúNo Authentication‚Äù and click OK button.
4.  Open ‚ÄòManage NuGet Package for Solution‚Ä¶‚Äô.
5.  Click ‚ÄúBrowse‚Äù tab and click a package.

**Expected Result:**
The vertical scrollbar in the right pane show correctly in the default layout of Package Manager UI Window.

**Actual Result:**
The vertical scrollbar in the right pane is truncated in the default layout of Package Manager UI Window as below screenshot. It thinner than normal scrollbar, so it is hard to select.
![verticalscrollbar](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/20632625/17510336/1554226e-5e51-11e6-911a-145a9cbd5aaa.png)
**Note:**
1. It happened on Dev15 Preview4 Willow install+NuGet 3.6.0-Beta1-1738.
2. It repro on Dev14 U3+NuGet 3.5.0-RTM-1737.
3. It doesn‚Äôt repro on VS2015Update3 w/ NuGet 3.4.4.
4. It will not repro after you drag the right-boundary of the window to the right side.
5. The scrollbar will disappear when you drag the right-boundary of the window to the left side.

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "[Test Failure] The same package source gets two different tooltips" (#4330) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
**NuGet Version:** NuGet 4.0.0-RTM-2224
**VS Version:** D15Rel 26118.00
**OS Version:** Windows 10 RS1_Release 14393.726.170112-1758
 
**Repro Steps:**
1.  Create a new C# Console Application via VS.
2.  Right-click on the project and click ‚ÄòManage NuGet Packages‚Ä¶‚Äô.
3.  Hover on ‚ÄòPackage source‚Äô drop down list on the right-top of PM UI (default is ‚Äònuget.org‚Äô).
4.  Switch to other package source and switch back to ‚Äònuget.org‚Äô.
5.  Hover on ‚ÄòPackage source‚Äô drop down list again.

**Expected Result:**
The same package source gets same tooltips between step3 and step5.

**Actual Result:**
The same package source gets two different tooltips as below screenshot.
![differenttooltips](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/20632625/22099600/f73c8172-de66-11e6-88d7-b6f6f11f8889.png)

**Note:**
1. It repro on D15Rel 26118.00 (NuGet Client 4.0.0-RC3-2215).
2. It also repro on Dev14 MU3.5 25421.01(NuGet 3.4.4.1321).

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "[Test Failure]Project type showed ‚Äúunknown‚Äù when executing command ‚ÄúGet-Project‚Äù in PMC for .NET Core projects" (#7798) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
NuGet version: NuGet Client Dev\5.0.0.5831
Build Tools VS Version: D16.0\28613.55
OS: Windows 10 RS4_Release 17134.1.180410-1804
## Detailed repro steps 
1. Create a .NET Core/.NET Standard projects in VS.
2. Open PMC and execute command ‚ÄúGet-Project‚Äù in PMC.
## Expected
The project type showed correctly as below screenshot (e.g. ASP.NET Empty Web Site).
![correcttype](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/52775539-e05f5c00-307a-11e9-9e0f-c4249471f759.png)

## Actual
The project type showed ‚Äúunknown‚Äù as below screenshot.
![unknowntype](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/52775522-d3db0380-307a-11e9-8e5d-0cd799f82d91.png)

## Note
1. It only repro for .NET Core/.NET Standard projects.
2. It repro on D16.0\28613.55 (default NuGet Client 5.0.0.5821).
3. It repro on D15.8\27924.00 (default NuGet Client 4.8.0.5348).

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "[Bug Bash][Accessibility][Test Failure] Resizing the PMC window splitter to left makes the list a mess" (#8116) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
[658461](https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/658461)

Repro steps: 

1. Launch VS and create a C# Blank App (Universal Windows).

2. Open ‚ÄúPackage Manager Console‚Äù.

3. Drag the PMC window splitter to right.

4. Type ‚ÄòGet-Package -Updates‚Äô in PMC.

5. Drag the PMC window splitter to left and observe the content in PMC.

Expected:

The list should be wrapped intelligently.

 Actual:

Resizing the PMC window splitter to left makes the list a mess.

 

Notes:

1. The issue repro on D16.0stg 28002.3000 (default NuGet Client Release-4.8.0-preview3/4.8.0.5278).

2. The issue repro on D15.8 28002.3000 + NuGet Client Release-4.8.0-RTM\4.8.0.5374.

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "[Bug Bash][Test Failure] The ‚ÄòProjectName‚Äô column lost in PMC after resetting window layout" (#8117) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
[658342](https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/658342)

Repro steps: 

1. Launch VS and create a C# Blank App (Universal Windows).

2. Open ‚ÄúPackage Manager Console‚Äù.

3. Drag the PMC window splitter to right.

4. Type ‚ÄòGet-Package -Updates‚Äô in PMC.

5. Click ‚Äúwindow->Reset Window Layouts‚Äù.

6. Open ‚ÄúPackage Manager Console‚Äù and type ‚ÄòGet-Package -Updates‚Äô in PMC again.

7. Drag the PMC window splitter to right and observe the package information.

Expected:

The ‚ÄòProjectName‚Äô column should be displayed in step 7 such as step 4.

Actual:

The ‚ÄòProjectName‚Äô column lost in step 7 as attachment picture. 

Notes:

1. The issue repro on D16.0stg 28002.3000 (default NuGet Client Release-4.8.0-preview3/4.8.0.5278).

2. The issue repro on D15.8 28002.3000 + NuGet Client Release-4.8.0-RTM\4.8.0.5374.

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "[Bug Bash][Accessibility][Test Failure] Navigation by ‚ÄúTab‚Äù doesn‚Äôt work in PMC window" (#8118) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
NuGet Version: NuGet Client 5.0.0.5371

VS Version: D16.0stg 27930.3001

OS Version: Windows 10 RS4_Release 17134.1.180410-1804

 

Installation steps: 

1.     Install VS: \\cpvsbuild\drops\VS\D16.0stg\products\27930.3001\bootstrappers\Enterprise\vs_enterprise.exe

2.     Install NuGet Client: \\ddfiles\Drops\NuGet\Drops\CI\NuGet.Client\dev\5.0.0.5371\artifacts\VS15\NuGet.Tools.vsix

 

Repro steps: 

1. Launch VS and create a C# Class Library (.NET Framework).

2. Navigate to the menu Tools->NuGet Package Manager->Package Manager Console to open the PMC.

3. Tab through the PMC window.

 

Expected:

Navigation by ‚ÄúTab‚Äù works well.

 

Actual:

Navigation by ‚ÄúTab‚Äù doesn‚Äôt work in PMC window as attached screenshot (no rectangle show when hitting ‚ÄòTab‚Äô).

 

Note:

1. It doesn‚Äôt repro on PM UI.

2. It repro on D16.0stg 27930.3001 (default NuGet Client 4.8.0.5278) and D15.9stg 27930.3001 (default NuGet Client 4.8.0.5348).

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Restore error summary" (#12522) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

MSBuild.exe, dotnet.exe

### The Elevator Pitch

When updating a very large legacy monorepo to SDK-style projects, NuGet restore spewed out **thousands** of errors. It was difficult to browse through all the text and identify the root causes. I created a small summary tool using the binlog parser and regex error message grouping (which removed project-specific text), and it proved most helpful:

```cs
#r "nuget: MSBuild.StructuredLogger, 2.1.790"
using Microsoft.Build.Logging.StructuredLogger;

var log = BinaryLog.ReadBuild(@"msbuild.binlog");
var errors = log.FindChildrenRecursive<Error>().DumpAs(t => t.Count);
errors.GroupBy(c => c.Code).Select(c => (code: c.Key, messages: c.GroupBy(m => ResolveText(c.Key, m.Text), m => m.File))).Dump();

static string ResolveText(string code, string text) => code switch
	{
		"NU1602" => Regex.Match(text, @"for dependency ([-\w\.]+)\.").Value,
		"NU1605" or "NU1109" => Regex.Match(text, @"Detected package downgrade: ([-\w\.]+) from ([-\w\.]+) to (centrally defined)? ([-\w\.]+)").Value,
		"NU1603" => Regex.Match(text, @"([-\w\.]+) ([-\w\.]+) depends on ([-\w\.]+) \(>= ([-\w\.]+)\)").Value,
		_ => text
	};
```

The output looks something like this:
```
- NU1202
  - Package x.y 1.2.3 is not compatible with ...
    - path/to/p1.csproj
    - path/to/p2.csproj
  - Package a.b 3.4.5 is not compatible with ...
    - path/to/p3.csproj
- NU1605
  - Detected package downgrade: x.y ...
    - path/to/p4.csproj

```

I propose that the restore target of a root traversal project optionally emit such a text summary at the end. For error grouping, perhaps use the `ShortenedText` property and remove project-specific data from it.

### Additional Context and Details

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "[Test Failure][Suggestion] Link ‚Äúhttps://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/reference/migrate-packages-config-to-package-reference‚Äù should be clickable in migration-failed dialog" (#8274) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
VS Version: D16.2stg 29027.113
OS Version: 17763.RS5_Release.180914-1434.
Install VS: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=2806963&view=results
Install NuGet:       \\\ddfiles\Drops\NuGet\Drops\CI\NuGet.Client\Dev\5.2.0.6067\artifacts\VS15\NuGet.Tools.vsix
## Detailed repro steps 
1. Launch Visual Studio 2019.
2. Create a new C++ Console App project and open PM UI in Solution Explorer window.
3. Install a package (e.g. Netonsoft.json) with ‚Äúpackages.config‚Äù format into the project.
4. Right-click the ‚ÄúReference‚Äù node and select the ‚ÄúMigrate packages.config to PackageReference‚Ä¶‚Äù.
5. Observe the warning.
## Expected
‚Äúhttps://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/reference/migrate-packages-config-to-package-reference‚Äù should be a link in migration-failed dialog.
## Actual
Link ‚Äúhttps://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/reference/migrate-packages-config-to-package-reference‚Äù does not clickable in migration-failed dialog as below screenshot.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40230425/60334817-f7ba3880-99ce-11e9-860d-80c51b44bd45.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet should use a different property for the platform version for C++/CLI" (#12521) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "Signing:  raise actionable message on Linux if verification results in untrusted failure" (#12459) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
When signed package verification fails on Linux, we should raise an actionable message with a link to a document that explains https://github.com/dotnet/designs/blob/main/accepted/2021/signed-package-verification/re-enable-signed-package-verification-technical.md#linux and how to curate a sufficiently complete certificate bundle.

CC @aortiz-msft

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "dotnet list package returns error if solution includes a docker-compose project" (#12520) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Affected

dotnet.exe

### Current Behavior

This is likely related to the behavior change described here: https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/12479

My organization has a pipeline step that lists vulnerable packages for our ASP.NET Core soutions using:

`dotnet list <soution>.sln package --vulnerable --include-transitive`

After updating our toolchain from dotnet 6 to dotnet 7, this command now returns a non-zero error code for all of our projects even if no vulnerable packages are found. We get an error message:

`The project <path>\docker-compose.dcproj` uses package.config for NuGet packages, while the command works only with package reference projects.`

Which seems to be the source of the error.

### Desired Behavior

Ideally, there would be some way to tell the tool to ignore the docker-compose.csproj file since it is irrelevant to this scan.

Failing that, treating the incompatible file as a warning and not an error would allow us to detect actual issues with the tool.

### Additional Context

 It's very easy to reproduce this without any custom code.

1. In Visual Studio 2022, create a new ASP.NET Core Web API project. Include Docker support.
2. A new solution will be created. Right-click on the WebApplication1 project in Solution Explorer and select Add > Container Orchestrator Support. Choose the Docker Compose option. This will create a new docker-compose.csproj file.
3. Open a PowerShell prompt and run `dotnet list <soution>.sln package`. No need to even check for vulnerabilities.
4. Check `$LASTEXITCODE` and see that it is `1`. 

We have been forced to disable this check due to this behavior. I found an old issue: https://github.com/microsoft/MSBuildSdks/issues/131

Which suggests a possible workaround of defining the `RestoreProjectStyle` setting in the problem project. But the workaround is not valid for the docker-compose project, which does not have NuGet dependencies.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed pull request "Rename SECURITY.md to SECURITY.xml" (#12512) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "Moving to the new .NET Foundation CLA service" (#68) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Hello everyone
The .NET Foundation is transitioning to a new CLA service and I'm posting here to let you know it's happening. Some background info:

The new CLA service is based off of https://github.com/microsoft/ContributorLicenseAgreement, except it uses the dotnet-policy-service app

- Current contributors do not need to sign the CLA again
- The CLA agreement itself is not changing
- As part of the install/configuration process, the following work items will be completed

1. Create a .github repo if it doesn't exist already
2. Install the dotnet-policy-service app
3. Create PRs for the platformcontext.xml and cla.yml files
4. Disable the existing CLA webhook
5. Push the PRs to enable the new CLA service

That's all there is to it. I'll update this issue once the work is complete

Thanks
Chris
.NET Foundation Operations team

That's all there is to it. I'll update this issue once the work is complete

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGet.org migration towards a new multi-CDN infrastructure" (#60) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
In the coming weeks, nuget.org will be migrating towards a new multi-CDN infrastructure that will improve the experience of our users. This change allows our team flexibility to switch to a back-up provider in the case that one CDN is down, which will broaden coverage for our users.

Some changes are coming for older TLS cipher suites, which may result in connectivity issues. From our data we believe this will affect only a small percentage of requests. We will be monitoring all feedback channels during the migration to assess impact and adjust our roll-out timeline as needed.

Below, we provide resources to determine whether you will be affected by this change. This utilizes the [.NET CLI](https://dotnet.microsoft.com/) to install a package from our pre-production (INT) environment which tests connectivity:


```
mkdir cdn-test
cd cdn-test
dotnet new classlib
dotnet add package BaseTestPackage.NetStandard --source https://apiint.nugettest.org/v3/index.json
```

If you are experiencing connectivity issues while connecting to nuget.org or restoring packages from https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json, such as:

"The SSL connection could not be established"

Please ensure that TLS 1.2 and any of the following cipher suites have been enabled on your machine:

TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256
TLS_DHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384
TLS_DHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256

If you have any questions, do reach out to us at‚ÄØsupport@nuget.org or by commenting on the discussion issue:‚ÄØNuGet/Home#11058
